awd_titl_txt: Microbial Oceanography Links to New aerosols in Ice-covered Regions (MjOLNIR) in the Arctic Ocean
awd_abstract_narration:
The most dramatic environmental changes occurring on the Earth today are taking place in the Arctic Ocean. Recent models predict that complete summertime Arctic sea ice loss will likely occur in the first half of the 21st century. The rapidly-declining areal expanse of summer pack ice will lead to changes in microbial community structure and production within both sea-ice communities and in the open waters of the Arctic Ocean. As summer sea ice microbial communities are replaced by open ocean populations, identifying changes in chemical compounds, such as various aerosols, that are released to the atmosphere might play a significant role in determining the future rate and impact of sea ice decline. The aerosols produced by microorganisms will ultimately move across the sea to air boundary and could affect cloud formation and with feedbacks that impact the Arctic system.  In this study, the investigators will use state-of-the art methods to measure the relative abundances of aerosols that are associated with the microbial communities found in sea ice, melt ponds, sea ice leads, and in the open ocean. Better understanding of the changes in the structure of these microbial communities will provide new information for the next generation of models and may lead to more sophisticated understanding of various climate feedback loops. In addition, the project involves a collaboration with Swedish polar researchers and will strengthen scientific linkages between scientists in the USA and Sweden. The project will support training for graduate and undergraduate students, and the investigators will share research results with the public through lectures, as part of the Cultivate Program, and social media. 

The investigators will investigate how in-situ microbial community composition and productivity in contrasting sea-ice and open-ocean Arctic ecosystems impact the production and release of biogenic, volatile organic carbon (VOC) compounds. These VOC compounds are instrumental in the release and production of aerosols that ultimately form cloud condensation nuclei. In addition, the investigators will perform shipboard manipulative experiments to determine the effects of elevated sea surface temperatures, enhanced light intensities, and lower salinities resulting from melting sea ice and enhanced water column stratification. These changes will impose physiological stress on microbial communities that is likely to impact both phytoplankton community structure and the flux of the biogenic sulfur trace gas dimethylsulfide (DMS). The investigators will test how temperature, salinity, and light will affect the composition of the microbial community and thereby the catabolic fate of the DMS precursor dimethylsulfoniopropionate (DMSP), to yield either DMS or methanethiol and methane (CH4). In addition, the investigators will test whether the high CH4 concentrations observed in Arctic Ocean surface waters are due to DMSP catabolism or, alternatively, the breakdown of methylphosphonate. Using state-of-the-art instrumentation, they will monitor VOC fluxes using a shipboard Proton Transfer Reaction Mass Spectrometer (PTR-MS), a Membrane Inlet Mass Spectrometer, and high speed sorting flow cytometer to measure VOCs, net community production, and microbial community composition, respectively. They will make direct measurements of VOCs within sea ice by using a newly developed ice crusher attached to the PTR-MS to provide new in-situ data on the concentrations of DMS and CH4 in sea ice communities.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding the rapidly changing Arctic climate, and of the processes that shape it, is key to projecting the future of this unique region, and the climate impact on society. Over the last several decades, warming in the Arctic region has been occurring at ~ twice the global average, with the most obvious consequence being a rapidly diminishing sea ice extent and mass. There is not yet a clear understanding of the strong feedback mechanisms between a warming Arctic Ocean and its impact on ecological changes to this ecosystem.

 

The main objective of the joint US-Sweden expedition to the North Pole aboard the Swedish icebreaker RVIB Oden was to investigate changes in atmospheric-oceanic coupling during the late summer-early autumn transition when sea ice starts to form. Our component on the expedition documented hydrographic and biogeochemical changes in the water column during this transitional Sea ice loss rates during the summer were significant and resulted in low salinity water at the surface. Consequently, the water column was stably density stratified with little mixing from deeper nutrient rich waters. Rates of oceanic primary production and phytoplankton biomass decreased during the August to September period. The phytoplankton community composition has changed relative to past conditions when the photosynthetic community was dominated by sea ice diatoms. We observed the phytoplankton community in the water column to be dominated by small phytoplankton species such as prasinophytes. This change in phytoplankton community composition will impact the flux of organic carbon to the deep ocean as well as impact the trophic foodweb. We conducted nutrient bioassay experiments that revealed that the phytoplankton community growing under the ~ 1m ice surface was co-limited by both light and nutrients. While enhanced sea ice melt in the coming decades should alleviate light limitation effects, the reduced water column mixing will likely exacerbate nutrient limited effects. As the extent and duration of open, ice-free waters in the Central Arctic Ocean progressively increases, our findings suggest that enhanced light transmission could potentially expand the ecological niche of the small phytoplankton Pyramimonas spp. in the region at the expense of sea ice diatoms. This change will significantly impact the Arctic carbon cycle.

 

Our project also focused on the presence of the volatile trace gas, dimethylsulfide (DMS) and its precursor dimethylsulfoniopropionate (DMSP) in the water column. DMS fluxes across the ocean to air interface can mediate cloud formation via the production of cloud condensation nuclei. Hence environmental factors impacting DMS fluxes can be important in regulating cloud cover in the high Arctic Ocean. Cloud cover plays a dynamic role in affecting climate processes and oceanic ecosystem structure. Due to the low abundances of sea ice diatoms (high producers of DMSP) we expected that the DMS levels in the water column would be relatively low. Our results corroborated this hypothesis as very low (near detectable levels) of DMS were measured. Interestingly, DMSP concentrations were measurable and highest during the late summer period.  Of the nine phytoplankton taxonomic groups identified, DMSP was most closely correlated with a small prasinophytes species such as Pyramimonas spp. This species has not usually been considered a high DMSP producer. Future studies should address the potential of small pico-phytoplankton species in producing DMSP.

 

Our project supported and trained both undergraduate and graduate students. Students were involved in both data collection at sea and analytical measurements in the laboratory. The project was also able to support the training of a research assistant at sea. Data was shared with scientists at national meetings as well as with our international collaborators in Sweden during several workshops. The outreach component included giving talks at local organizations such as the Rotary Club of Charleston as well as to local K-12 school groups including Montessori schools.
